ItemSource.SourceLine: mLogger.LogKarelEvent "Turn On at street " + str(mStreet) + " avenue " + str(mAvenue), self
Sub Constructor(optionalGraphics as Graphics=nil, inWorld as KarelWorld = nil)
// steps to move by in a given direction - Avenues run horizontally, coords increase up and right
// note that the directions are 1-4 for compatibility with the Java version so the deltas have a blank first delta
// which you could also consider as going nowhere ;-)
// Karel initial state but probably override with a map
mDirection = North // ensure a legal value!

Method.ItemParams: optionalGraphics as Graphics=nil, inWorld as KarelWorld = nil

ItemSource.SourceLine: Function Street2Y(atStreet as integer) As integer
ErrorShutdown "Street greater than number of streets - " + str(numS)
// Y coords are flipped - streets are higher closer to top of screen
dim retY as integer = Round(mWorld.Margin + flippedStreet * mCachedGapY)
Function Avenue2X(atAvenue as integer) As integer
ErrorShutdown "Avenue greater than number of avenues - " + str(numA)
dim retX as integer = Round(mWorld.Margin + atAvenue * mCachedGapX)
dim targetMicroS as double = startMicroS + numSeconds * 1000000.0
// loop trying to sleep in one chunk but coping if it doesn't sleep as long
if sleepMilliS <= 0 then exit // delay at millisecond resolution
Wait MovePause // this implements the speed of playback
mLogger.LogKarelEvent "Move to street " + str(mStreet) + " avenue " + str(mAvenue), self
Wait MovePause // this implements the speed of playback
if mLogger is nil then return
return mWorld.IsWallBetween( mAvenue, mStreet, NextAvenue, NextStreet )
mLogger.LogKarelEvent "Pick Beeper at street " + str(mStreet) + " avenue " + str(mAvenue), self
ErrorShutdown "Beeper not at location when tried to PickBeeper"
ErrorShutdown "No beepers left in bag - unable to PutBeeper"
mLogger.LogKarelEvent "Put Beeper at street " + str(mStreet) + " avenue " + str(mAvenue), self
// WARNING calling this will do things to reset the robot so only call if world actually reloaded
// step from one avenue to the next in pixels
dim numGaps as double = mWorld.NumAvenues+1 // gap either side of lines
// step from one street to the next in pixels
dim numGaps as double = mWorld.NumStreets+1 // gap either side of lines
Shared Function PrepareKarelScript(inScript as String) As String
// find if the code contains a
// or multiple variables dim i, k as
// but not smart enough to pickup dim k, i as
// because that is getting very paranoid
// if not defined, we will insert one
if rp.Search( inScript ) is nil then
inScript = "dim i as integer" + EndOfLine + inScript
Function IsFrameBlockingDirection(inDirection as integer) As Boolean
if mStreet = mWorld.NumStreets then return true
if mAvenue = mWorld.NumAvenues then return true
// update increments that depend on number of avenues and streets, would also need to recalc if resize physical Graphics mDest

ItemSource.NoteLine: This is the class used to provide the context object for an RBScript running Karel.
It inherits many graphics operations from GraphicsScripter which are in turn visible as methods and properties
in the script. One reason for using inheritance is to keep the list of methods and properties here a lot
smaller so it's easier for people to understand pure Karel stuff.

Note.ItemName: Mapping between Street/Avenue and Graphics coordinates

ItemSource.NoteLine: Mapping between Street/Avenue and Graphics coordinates
For the graphics primitives to be used by Karel world objects, we must map their coordinates of Avenue, Street
to the X, Y coordinates of a graphics world.
There is also the question of an inset margin because the KarelWorld draws a boundary.
There are four functions presenting graphics coordinates to the user and clients such as KarelRobot, KarelWorld etc. for drawing:
We have width and height inherited from GraphicsScripter as the size of the canvas on which we're operating.
These are inset by mWorld.Margin to allow it to draw a frame around the area.
Thus the maximum horizontal drawing area is width - 2*Margin, on which we have mWorld.NumAvenues
The maximum vertical drawing area is height - 2*Margin on which we have mWorld.NumStreets
